title: Quick plays : Magic , Azzurri claim NPL crowns and mixed fortunes for Knights
body_text:
It was absolute heartbreak for Knights fans on Saturday night as they watched their team's season end in cruel circumstances in North Queensland.

Captain Kalyn Ponga, who was integral in securing a finals berth for Newcastle, was left to rue a moment he wished he could have again that looked certain to end in a try only for the ball to get knocked on.
Post-match, coach Adam O'Brien, who has steered Newcastle to four finals series in five seasons, declared they were proud of their efforts this year but not content.
Earlier on Saturday, the Knights' NRLW side kept alive their hopes of a third straight premiership crown with the club's biggest ever win.
In the must-win exchange and grand final rematch, Newcastle never gave the Titans a chance in the NRLW's penultimate round on the Gold Coast.
The 36-point victory may have, however, come at a cost with props Simone Karpani (foot), Rima Butler (knee) and Nita Maynard (ankle) all limping off and unable to finish the game.
The Knights ended the weekend in fourth place by points differential and now face another must-win clash in Townsville on Saturday to seal a finals place.
Magic, Azzurri crowned champions
In what will go down as one of the best Northern NSW Football top-division deciders, Broadmeadow prevailed in a penalty shoot-out over Edgeworth at Magic Park on Saturday afternoon.
Both teams had a player sent off and Magic came from behind twice to send the grand final into extra-time.
When they couldn't be separated after that, the game was determined in spot kicks with Magic defender Tom Beecham, who was named player of the grand final, sealing the 2-2 (4-3) victory.
It was Broadmeadow's first grand final win since 2018.
On Sunday at Darling Street Oval, the NPL Women's championship decider was a five-goal thriller played out in at times torrential rain and cyclonic winds.
Charlestown Azzurri secured their first grand final victory in the competition with an entertaining 3-2 win over Newcastle Olympic.
Olympic were playing in their fourth straight grand final and had the opportunity to level the match midway through the second half only for captain Jemma House to send her penalty shot agonisingly wide of the left post.
Ella Joyce, who travels up from Castle Hill to play with Azzurri and turns 22 this week, earned the inaugural Joey Peters Medal for player of the grand final after producing spectacular goals in either half.
Oxfords set up GF rematch
Maiden top-grade goals from young guns Jonti Adamson and Christine Fernance gave Oxfords a shot at back-to-back Newcastle women's premier league hockey titles.
The win sets up a rematch with Gosford, who beat Oxfords 3-1 last week. Oxfords, this year's minor premiers, beat Gosford in last season's decider.
In the Hunter Coast Premier Hockey League men's preliminary final, Gosford beat Wests 3-1 on Sunday and meet Norths in the decider.
What else happened?
The Entrance will face Central for a spot in the Newcastle Rugby League grand final after defeating South Newcastle in the minor semi at Cessnock on Sunday.
In the second of two semis over the weekend, after Maitland beat Central on Saturday, the Tigers outclassed a depleted Souths side 28-10 on a cool afternoon at Baddeley Park.
Nelson Bay flyer Maya Stewart crossed for two tries as the Wallaroos were stung 36-10 by Ireland in Belfast early Sunday morning (AEST).
